author: @ashok_learn
text: If you want to do y.backward() Do this:  y = torch.sum(torch_input**3+torch_input**2) y.backward() print(torch_input.grad)   PS. Because the y should be a scalar value in order to do the backward

author: @theturingtest7476
text: Thanks . Appreciate your videos . This one confused me though . Ideally the .backward() is done on the loss . In your example , your loss function is sum(x**3+x**2 . ) . and your finding the gradient dloss/dx  using .x.grad function .  It would have been less confusing if you would have made a function , created a loss function using mean square error and did a gradient .
